metadata.case_name: Mansoor & Ors. v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: All ten accused charged under ss. 302/34, 302/149, 307/34, 307/149 IPC for murder of Karamat Beg Pahalwan and attempt to murder Iqbal Beg on January 19, 1965 at 12:30 PM at Bombay Bazar Choraha, Indore.
Eight accused additionally charged under ss. 302, 307, 148 IPC.

Trial Court (Additional Sessions Judge, Indore) convicted Mansoor, Rashid, Ishaq, Yunus under s. 302/34 and s. 324/34 IPC (injury to Iqbal Beg), sentenced to life and 6 months RI; acquitted rest giving benefit of doubt.
Trial Court found injuries 2, 3, 9 on deceased sufficient to cause death but no specific accused linked to fatal injury; relied on common intention per Mathura Lal Adi Reddy v. State of Hyderabad.
Gabbu acquitted as not in possession of weapon and no knowledge of object.

High Court (MP HC, Indore Bench, April 21, 1966) upheld conviction of four, convicted Mehmood s/o Bhondekhan additionally; held ss. 302/34, 302/149, 148, 324/34/149 proved against five; sentenced under 148 to 1 year RI; dismissed revision for death sentence.

Prosecution story: Factions - Mansoor's group (smugglers: Mansoor, servants Ishaq, Yunus, Gabbu, Rashid friend, Pathans Ajimkhan, Hakimkhan, Mahmoodkhan) vs Karamat Beg and son Iqbal; prior quarrels, s.107 CrPC proceedings.

Incident: Karamat proceeding along Jawahar Marg to Bombay Bazar on Jan 19, 1965 (Ramzan); met Ishaq/Yunus who spat; chased to near Grand National Bakery where Mansoor; Mansoor directed assault; Rashid knifed Karamat; Mansoor suggested cut veins, inflicted blows; Yunus/Ishaq grappled; Iqbal intervened with stick but injured on hand/arm by Ishaq/Mehmood; Karamat unconscious; Iqbal lodged FIR.

Defence: List of 13 witnesses filed in Sessions Court, not in Magistrate; absent on June 10, 1965; adjournment to June 11 denied further; plea of alibi for most; only Munshi Khan examined later per SC order.
Munshi Khan (defence witness): Saw Karamat abuse/attack Mansoor with stick near Agra Hotel; Mansoor bled, taken to PS by Chhotekhan; denied Iqbal had stick or accused present except Mansoor.
SC allowed defence evidence on Sep 22, 1970; only Munshi examined; counsel later not interested.
Mahmood s/o Bhondekhan served sentence, out of jail.

legal_issues.text: Whether conviction of five accused under ss. 302/34, 302/149, 148, 324/34/149 IPC sustainable.
Whether High Court erred in reversing acquittal of Mehmood s/o Bhondekhan and applying ss. 148/149.
Whether prejudice caused by Trial Court refusing adjournment for defence witnesses.
Whether State appeal against acquittal in High Court competent (Additional Govt Advocate as Public Prosecutor).
Whether acquittal of remaining five justified; State seeks enhancement to death.

petitioner_arguments.text: Eye-witnesses (Iqbal PW1, Ahmed Khan PW2 etc.) unreliable, interested, inconsistencies with site plan (Narayan Singh PW25), FIR not first (Mansoor reported earlier), case diary defects.
Prejudice from Trial Court closing defence without adjournment for alibi witnesses.
High Court did not follow standard for acquittal appeals (Sanwat Singh, Keshav Ganga Ram).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan (1961) 3 SCR 120; Keshav Ganga Ram Navge v. State of Maharashtra

petitioner_arguments.text: State appeal incompetent as Additional Govt Advocate not Public Prosecutor for acquittal appeals.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.417, 492 CrPC; Bhiniappa Bassappa v. Laxman (AIR 1970 SC 1153)

petitioner_arguments.text: Munshi Khan's evidence supports self-defence/provocation by Karamat.

court_reasoning.text: Under Art.136, no re-appraisal of evidence/credibility unless illegality, procedural irregularity, natural justice violation or gross miscarriage; no infirmity shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court accepted eye-witness version after sifting factional evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Munshi Khan's evidence unimpressive, unworthy of serious consideration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defence allowed belatedly; only one witness examined.

court_reasoning.text: High Court followed principles for acquittal appeals (Sanwat Singh, Sheo Swarup); gave reasons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No ignoring of Trial Court reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Conviction under 302/34 stands even if 148/149 not; no error in Mahmood's conviction.
Additional Govt Advocate notified as Public Prosecutor for High Court cases in MP State; appeal competent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Objection not raised in High Court; s.4(1)(i), 492 CrPC.

holdings.text: Convictions under ss. 302/34, 302/149, 148, 324/34/149 upheld; no interference under Art.136.
State appeal against remaining acquittals not interfered with.
High Court appeal against acquittal competent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mathura Lal Adi Reddy v. State of Hyderabad
Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles for appeals against acquittal; Art.136 limits
Appellate court principles in acquittal appeals

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshav Ganga Ram Navge v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.citation: Cr. A. No. 100/130 of 1968, decided Feb 3, 1971
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court must dispel Trial Court reasons in acquittal reversal

precedents_cited.case_name: Laxman Kalu Nikalje v. State of Maharashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Powers in acquittal vs conviction appeals

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhiniappa Bassappa Bhu Sannavat v. Laxman Shivrayappa Samagouda

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges for murder, attempt to murder, rioting, common intention, unlawful assembly

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings between parties; appeals against acquittal; Public Prosecutor appointment

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave appeals; limits on evidence re-appraisal

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals by convicted accused; did not interfere with High Court's reversal of acquittal for Mehmood or acquittals of remaining five; upheld sentences including life imprisonment.

key_quotes.text: under Art. 136 of the Constitution this Court does not normally re-appraise the evidence for considering the credibility of the witnesses as if it is a court of first appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: This evidence seems to us to be wholly unimpressive and does not call for any serious consideration or comment.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the High Court has not contravened any of the principles laid down in Sheo Swarup's case and has also given reasons which led it to hold that the acquittal was not justified.
key_quotes.speaker: court
